Lead Story
Exclusive Investigation

Commissioner Peck Announces "Soup Is Stable," Orders All Citizens to Stop Asking

By Reginald Peck III, Commissioner • Office of the Coop

Citizens of the Greater Metropolitan Pigeon Authority: your soup is safe. I repeat — your soup is safe. I am writing this from the Commissioner's Perch, where I have governed wisely and without scandal for eleven consecutive years, and I want to address the rumors directly.

The rumors are false. All of them. I haven't even heard them, and they're false.

Let me be clear about several things at once. First: the soup reserve is at an all-time high of 340,000 liters. This is a real number that I did not invent. Second: the tide-based menu system is functioning exactly as designed. If your order was voided during Tuesday's unexpected neap tide, that is the ocean's fault, not mine. I do not control the moon. I have tried.

Third, and I cannot stress this enough: stop hoarding chowder. We have surveillance footage of at least forty citizens burying mason jars in Riverside Park. You know who you are. The soil there is too acidic for proper soup storage anyway — everyone knows this.

My administration has brought you 11 years of mostly uninterrupted soup-based commerce. Before I took office, pigeons were bartering in breadcrumbs. Breadcrumbs. Like animals. I gave you a currency you can also eat, and this is the thanks I get — questions. Endless questions.

The game show will continue on its regular schedule. Yes, I am both the host and the head of government. No, this is not a conflict of interest. The game show is how we determine restaurant licensing. This is normal. Every civilization does this.

In closing: everything is fine. The tides are fine. The soup is fine. I am fine. Stop asking.

— Commissioner Reginald Peck III, Order of the Crust, Defender of the Broth

"I do not control the moon. I have tried." — Commissioner Reginald Peck III, in today's address

Opinion & Editorial
OPINION

I Ate My Entire Savings And I'd Do It Again

By Francine DuBeak • Guest Columnist

Last Thursday at approximately 2:15 PM, I consumed 340 Standard Soup Units. That's my rent. That's my children's education fund. That was, technically, three hundred and forty individual servings of minestrone, and I drank every last one.

People say I'm irresponsible. The Health Department sent me a letter. My landlord (a crow — don't get me started) is threatening eviction. But here's what none of them understand: it was really good minestrone.

The Commissioner wants us to believe that soup can be both food and money. Fine. Then I made an investment — in my stomach. When the economy collapses (and it will; the gazpacho ban was the first domino), at least I'll be the pigeon who isn't hungry.

My financial advisor, a robin who I'm fairly sure is not licensed, told me I have "negative net broth." I told him that's not a real concept. He showed me a spreadsheet. It was just a napkin with soup stains on it. I ate the napkin. It was Category B pricing.

To the citizens reading this: live your truth. The tides change. The menus change. Your soup is the only thing that's really yours — until you drink it, and then it's really yours.

"I made an investment — in my stomach." — Francine DuBeak, moments before declaring bankruptcy
EDITORIAL

The Game Show Is Fine. Stop Saying The Game Show Isn't Fine.

By The Editorial Board (Reginald Peck III)

Some have suggested that a game show should not determine who is allowed to serve food. These people are wrong, and frankly, unpatriotic. The Broth Gauntlet has produced 207 episodes of world-class entertainment and exactly 14 licensed restaurants. That's a 6.7% success rate. In what industry is 6.7% not considered excellent?

We will not be taking further questions. This editorial was written voluntarily and not under any duress from the Commissioner's office, which is a separate entity from this newspaper despite sharing a building, a budget, and a editor-in-chief.

OP-ED

My Son Wants To Be A Seagull And I Blame The Schools

By Doris Tailfeather • Concerned Parent

He came home last Tuesday and told me he wanted to "eat garbage off the beach and scream." I asked him where he learned this. He said "nature documentaries." We don't own a television. We are pigeons.

The school system has failed our children. When I was young, we learned the three pillars: cooing, walking in circles, and looking at bread from several angles before eating it. Now they teach "marine appreciation." My son can identify four types of kelp. He cannot identify soup.

REBUTTAL

Actually, The Moon Can Be Controlled, And The Commissioner Is A Coward For Not Trying Harder

By Anonymous (identity withheld by court order)

The Commissioner wrote in this very paper that he "does not control the moon" and that he "has tried." This is a half-truth at best. Sources within the GMPA confirm that the lunar control program was defunded in 2021 after the Commissioner redirected the budget to purchase a larger desk.

If the tides determine our menus, and the moon determines our tides, then controlling the moon is not a luxury — it is a food policy. The desk, while admittedly very large, does not feed anyone. Unless it's made of bread. It is not made of bread. I checked.

Letters to the Editor

Re: "Soup Is Stable" — No It Isn't, And You Know It Isn't

Dear Editor (Commissioner),

I have been a loyal citizen of the GMPA for nine years. I pay my soup taxes. I watch the game show. I do not hoard chowder (anymore). But I will not sit quietly while you tell me the economy is "fine" when I paid 14 soups for a single french fry last Tuesday. The fry wasn't even hot. It was room temperature. I have been room temperature my entire life and no one has ever charged me 14 soups for it.

— Beatrice Ruffleton, Ledge 47, District 3

Why Does The Game Show Have A "Drowning Round"?

Dear Editor,

My daughter competed on Season 14, Episode 203 of The Broth Gauntlet. She did well in the soup identification round and the crouton obstacle course. Then she was asked to swim. We are pigeons. We do not swim. She did not win the restaurant license. She is now afraid of bowls.

The drowning round has a 0% completion rate across all 207 episodes. Why does it exist? The Commissioner's office told me it "builds character" and "the ocean demands it." The ocean has never demanded anything from me personally and I find the claim suspicious.

— Anonymous (name withheld because my daughter is embarrassed)

I Am The Seagull From The Bisque Story And I Have Rights

Dear Editor,

The bisque was mine. I made it. With my own two wings. In international waters. The GMPA has no jurisdiction over international bisque and you know it. I will see you in court. My lawyer is a pelican. He has a very large mouth, both literally and in the legal sense. You have been warned.

— Kevin (full name withheld for legal reasons)
Corrections & Retractions
CORRECTION: In Tuesday's edition, we stated that the soup reserve contained 340,000 liters. The actual number is 340,000 liters. We are correcting this to confirm that we were already correct. The Commissioner requested this correction.
CORRECTION: Last week's obituary for Herbert Coo incorrectly stated he was survived by "approximately 200 relatives." The actual number is approximately 200. We regret the accuracy.
RETRACTION: The article "Commissioner Peck Seen Eating Currency In Private" has been retracted. The Commissioner was not eating currency. He was "testing it for quality." The photographer has been reassigned to the tide desk.
CORRECTION: We previously reported that the 5th Street wire achieved a record 300 simultaneous pigeons. It was 299. The 300th was a starling in disguise. He has been dealt with.
CORRECTION: An earlier version of this page listed gazpacho as legal tender. Gazpacho has been illegal south of 14th Street since March. We apologize to anyone who attempted to buy goods with cold tomato soup and was arrested.
RETRACTION: The op-ed "The Commissioner's Desk Is Too Large" has been retracted. The desk is the right size. The Commissioner's office informed us that the desk is, in fact, "exactly the size a desk should be, and anyone who disagrees is welcome to measure it, but they won't be allowed to because it's classified."
